snippet.textDisplay:
If there were a quark with zero mass, wouldn't the other quarks preferentially decay into that quark the same way the muon and tau particles decay into electrons? Or is there something else preventing this, such as that only applying to free particles, which quarks can never be due to confinement?

And if it had zero mass, could it even be bound in the first place?

Seems like a zero mass quark would be ruled out by observation unless either they all were zero mass, or at the very least the up and down were both zero mass.

Or maybe I'm missing something completely. I'm an Astrophys major, so my knowledge of particle physics is admittedly patchy... at best...
snippet.textOriginal:
If there were a quark with zero mass, wouldn't the other quarks preferentially decay into that quark the same way the muon and tau particles decay into electrons? Or is there something else preventing this, such as that only applying to free particles, which quarks can never be due to confinement?

And if it had zero mass, could it even *be* bound in the first place?

Seems like a zero mass quark would be ruled out by observation unless either they all were zero mass, or at the very least the up and down were both zero mass.

Or maybe I'm missing something completely. I'm an Astrophys major, so my knowledge of particle physics is admittedly patchy... at best...

snippet.textDisplay: So, there is a problem with the idea of using an artificially created magnetic field to change the axions back to protons. The calibration of a field that strong to create a focused point would require incredible tuning, and sense we live on a geo-magnetic object that fluctuates it's magnetic field, these calibrations can't be done. This experiment needs to be done in space away from geo-magnetic objects to achieve the fine point magnetic field to turn axions back to protons.
snippet.textOriginal: So, there is a problem with the idea of using an artificially created magnetic field to change the axions back to protons. The calibration of a field that strong to create a focused point would require incredible tuning, and sense we live on a geo-magnetic object that fluctuates it's magnetic field, these calibrations can't be done. This experiment needs to be done in space away from geo-magnetic objects to achieve the fine point magnetic field to turn axions back to protons.

snippet.textDisplay: why is it everyone seems to be looking for one thing that is dark matter, are they all really so stupid to think it is that easy. that one day one particle will pop up and fill the whole ? what whole ? the whole they had to fill in  astronomical simulations because they were not working the way they expected. matter was missing.  so they plugged the whole to get it to work right and poof someone called that "dark matter".  there is likely an arms length list of things that actually fit, along with a basic misunderstanding of some physics as well .

Hi Matt. i'm aware it is not concerning the topic but how would you deal with someone so far in smooth brain that the person answered basicly with "photons have mass otherwise they would not have energy" and "we dont know for sure, there is no evidence that photons cannot go faster than light" and "light can travel faster than light" and "gravity is curvature of spacetime ? What startrek sh*t is that?" and "light have mass cuz it is affected by gravity". I think i know enough to say it is not because of mass but curved spacetime and escape velocity beeing unreachable and for anything with mass you can go close but not at speed of light because it would require more and more energy to gain lower and lower acceleration up to infinite ammount of energy. I know i am not genious but c'mon even if i said it is because light is going straight and space is curved so curve is actually straight and if it crosses event horizon it is too slow to escape , wouldn't be so much of a "streach". And that person even wrote that, and i sh*t you not, light have mass because sun have mass, and sun losses mass. Is it just me? Am i stupid or something? I know milk has been spilled and i kinda went all road rage on that poor thing and went even so fas as to paste link to PBS Spacetime and told him/her to get a book, paper one, a legit book on physics and read.
I know i probably went a bit too harsh but still, how would you react, how You handle those types of situation.


It all went over a meme here https://9gag.com/gag/aPRpEjw?ref=w.commentupvotenoti#cs_comment_id=c_158158107493361512
and my comment is uder name krzlew96 ... i tried to be original but all the names were taken soo. And i know i probably made some mistakes there, i was a bit angry at the time so i ight have slipped a bit.


Im asking because i would like to learn how to answer to such comments.

snippet.textDisplay: Mystery. Intrepid scientist explorers, the phrase implying adventure and heroism, sacrifice. You can see why from the renaissance onward grew atheism, which gradually replaced religion as the fundamental narrative, the fundamental heroic narrative is partly present in its way, onwards and upwards, it has its laws and tenents, it has its unproven and unseen beliefs (dark matter, climate change) the same as every religion. It is also lacking in a way unlike religion. I can't quite put my finger on it but it feels wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: For the infinite typing monkeys, the "monkey" is only a metaphor anyway, which brings me to my take on the concept with the "infinite madden monkeys", where each monkey used their own copy of madden NFL (let's say madden NFL 20) to simulate the NFL season, right up to and including the Super Bowl, and even sim the future beyond that. Each sim differs from each other sim in some way, even if it's only really far into the future. Of course, one sim out of all of them would reflect what really happened, right up to and including the Chiefs' Super Bowl LIV victory over the 49ers. I would've put that as a comment on that last video, but my Switch (on which I was watching that video) wouldn't let me submit that comment...

snippet.textDisplay: 15:50 The square root of 10^10^123 is not 10^10^60; it's about 10^10^122.7 - which makes the argument even stronger, but the pedant in me cannot resist pointing out the mistake.
snippet.textOriginal: 15:50 The square root of 10^10^123 is not 10^10^60; it's about 10^10^122.7 - which makes the argument even stronger, but the pedant in me cannot resist pointing out the mistake.

snippet.textDisplay: VPN doesn't protect you from 3rd party ad providers tracking your traffic on the websites you visit because that is done through cookies. Most traffic on the important websites is also already encrypted with TLS 2.0, so even without VPN, no one can eavesdrop on your connection. Your home IP address is also dynamically assigned by the ISP (in other words, it changes) and doesn't really contain personally identifiable information (which, as I already said, is tracked through cookies). I'm honestly not sure what VPN is actually supposed to protect you from. I mean, thanks for sponsoring the video, I guess, but I kind of feel like you're taking advantage of the ignorance of the average person to push a (mostly) useless product.
snippet.textOriginal: VPN doesn't protect you from 3rd party ad providers tracking your traffic on the websites you visit because that is done through cookies. Most traffic on the important websites is also already encrypted with TLS 2.0, so even without VPN, no one can eavesdrop on your connection. Your home IP address is also dynamically assigned by the ISP (in other words, it changes) and doesn't really contain personally identifiable information (which, as I already said, is tracked through cookies). I'm honestly not sure what VPN is actually supposed to protect you from. I mean, thanks for sponsoring the video, I guess, but I kind of feel like you're taking advantage of the ignorance of the average person to push a (mostly) useless product.

I do, however, think it would be a good idea to see how well the frequency of that function correlates with time dilation in different relativistic frames, provided that's even possible to calculate.

snippet.textDisplay:
Hi! Thank you very much for your entertaining and educational videos!

I've had some trouble trying to understand Hawking Radiation.

If spacetime warping around a black hole asymptotically approaches infinite, how does anything ever cross the event horizon, from the perspective of an external observer?

If the particle were a photon, wouldn't it be infinitely redshifted by the time it reached an external observer, and thus be undetectable?

If it were a massive particle at a higher orbit, how would it reduce the overall energy of the black hole? Wouldn't the spontaneous creation of a real, energetic particle cause the black hole to expand, as its causally preceding particle was still slowing down in its infinite descent towards the event horizon?

To expect to be able to observe this radiation seems like a violation of causality and conservation of energy. How have I misinterpreted the phenomena involved?
snippet.textOriginal:
Hi! Thank you very much for your entertaining and educational videos!

I've had some trouble trying to understand Hawking Radiation.

If spacetime warping around a black hole asymptotically approaches infinite, how does anything ever cross the event horizon, from the perspective of an external observer?

If the particle were a photon, wouldn't it be infinitely redshifted by the time it reached an external observer, and thus be undetectable?

If it were a massive particle at a higher orbit, how would it reduce the overall energy of the black hole? Wouldn't the spontaneous creation of a real, energetic particle cause the black hole to expand, as its causally preceding particle was still slowing down in its infinite descent towards the event horizon?

To expect to be able to observe this radiation seems like a violation of causality and conservation of energy. How have I misinterpreted the phenomena involved?

snippet.textDisplay: Well, that whole pronunciation stuff is messy: In "proper" Latin, it should be [prinkipia] since that's how native speakers would have pronounced it. But we know that stuff only in recent times. Most likely, Newton himself would have pronounced it [prinsipia] or [printsipia]. So, this comes to the idea of "death of the author": Does it matter how the author conceived his own work?
snippet.textOriginal: Well, that whole pronunciation stuff is messy: In "proper" Latin, it should be [prinkipia] since that's how native speakers would have pronounced it. But we know that stuff only in recent times. Most likely, Newton himself would have pronounced it [prinsipia] or [printsipia]. So, this comes to the idea of "death of the author": Does it matter how the author conceived his own work?

snippet.textDisplay: Regarding the axions being the source of dark matter, I have always thought that one of the conditions for a good candidate to be the particle behind dark matter is that it must be cold i.e. no relativistic speeds so it can form large-scale structures. I believe neutrinos, whose mass is so small that they can travel to (almost) the speed of light, are discarded for this reason (and also because the mass does not add up). But would not axions, if they exist and their mass is also very small, be traveling at almost the speed of light too and thus be unable to form structures?
snippet.textOriginal: Regarding the axions being the source of dark matter, I have always thought that one of the conditions for a good candidate to be the particle behind dark matter is that it must be cold i.e. no relativistic speeds so it can form large-scale structures. I believe neutrinos, whose mass is so small that they can travel to (almost) the speed of light, are discarded for this reason (and also because the mass does not add up). But would not axions, if they exist and their mass is also very small, be traveling at almost the speed of light too and thus be unable to form structures?

snippet.textDisplay: Could axions be used to explain the detection of ultra-high energy cosmic rays, such as the Oh-My-God particle? An extremely high energy axion, above the GZK limit, could cross the Universe undisturbed. When it gets closer to Earth, it could covert into photons which then knock into a proton/atomic nucleus and send it barreling towards us. Given the extreme rarity of these detections and the ability for the axion to come from virtually anywhere in the observable Universe, even exceptionally low interaction cross-sections could be acceptable.
snippet.textOriginal: Could axions be used to explain the detection of ultra-high energy cosmic rays, such as the Oh-My-God particle? An extremely high energy axion, above the GZK limit, could cross the Universe undisturbed. When it gets closer to Earth, it could covert into photons which then knock into a proton/atomic nucleus and send it barreling towards us. Given the extreme rarity of these detections and the ability for the axion to come from virtually anywhere in the observable Universe, even exceptionally low interaction cross-sections could be acceptable.

snippet.textDisplay: Quantum theory says that are some states in this universe that are not definite. An indefinite state can not be a duplicate of itself so there can be no universe that is a duplicate.  In every possible duplicate universe  new possibilities even self contradictory ones can always arise.  The very idea of an identical universe is based on the hidden yet false assumption that there could be an infinite omniscient mind that could observe them. Even if that were true how would this omniscient mind know how many identical universes there are unless he can tell them apart.  If he can't tell them apart it would be one universe not many and if he could tell them apart they wouldn't be identical.

snippet.textDisplay: OK... Space is not really expanding -- it's more that our clocks are speeding up, which translates directly to an observed expansion of space, but this is mostly due to the clock rate. However, there is a slight imbalance in our vicinity between time speedup and apparent space expansion that manifests as a pseudoforce -- gravity.

Space is not really expanding -- it's more that our clocks are speeding up, which translates directly to an observed expansion of space, but this is mostly due to the clock rate. snippet.textDisplay:
In Latin of ancient Rome Principia was pronounced Prinkipia, because C was always pronounced K.
Wiki:
In the Latin-based orthographies of many European languages (including English), a distinction between hard and soft ⟨c⟩ occurs in which ⟨c⟩ represents two distinct phonemes. The sound of a hard ⟨c⟩ (which often precedes the non-front vowels ⟨a⟩, ⟨o⟩ and ⟨u⟩) is that of the voiceless velar stop, [k] (as in car) while the sound of a soft ⟨c⟩ (typically before ⟨e⟩, ⟨i⟩ and ⟨y⟩), depending on language, may be a fricative or affricate. In English, the sound of soft ⟨c⟩ is /s/ (as in "citrus").

There was no soft ⟨c⟩ in classical Latin, where it was always pronounced as /k/. Modern English pronunciation of early Latin often uses /s/ instead, as with Caesar (Latin pronunciation: [ˈkae̯sar]) becoming /ˈsiːzər/ SEE-zər.[1]
snippet.textOriginal:
In Latin of ancient Rome Principia was pronounced Prinkipia, because C was always pronounced K. 
Wiki:
In the Latin-based orthographies of many European languages (including English), a distinction between hard and soft ⟨c⟩ occurs in which ⟨c⟩ represents two distinct phonemes. The sound of a hard ⟨c⟩ (which often precedes the non-front vowels ⟨a⟩, ⟨o⟩ and ⟨u⟩) is that of the voiceless velar stop, [k] (as in car) while the sound of a soft ⟨c⟩ (typically before ⟨e⟩, ⟨i⟩ and ⟨y⟩), depending on language, may be a fricative or affricate. In English, the sound of soft ⟨c⟩ is /s/ (as in "citrus").

There was no soft ⟨c⟩ in classical Latin, where it was always pronounced as /k/. Modern English pronunciation of early Latin often uses /s/ instead, as with Caesar (Latin pronunciation: [ˈkae̯sar]) becoming /ˈsiːzər/ SEE-zər.[1]

On the Penrose diagram, is the «infinite space» from the right corner different from the one in the left corner since they don't represent directions but rather space in itself? snippet.textDisplay: About the pronounciation of "principia".. The latin pronounciation of C is known thanks to several poets that mused on the pronounciation of words when they were more and more influenced by the German tribes that knew a soft G. They differenciated the soft G from the hard C with a small symbol. The latin C is to be pronounced like a K sound and the word is pronounced like "prinkipia".
snippet.textOriginal: About the pronounciation of "principia".. The latin pronounciation of C is known thanks to several poets that mused on the pronounciation of words when they were more and more influenced by the German tribes that knew a soft G. They differenciated the soft G from the hard C with a small symbol. The latin C is to be pronounced like a K sound and the word is pronounced like "prinkipia".

snippet.textDisplay: Since the 6 quark particles are derived from a model which requires them to have mass, it doesn't work to solve the strong CP problem. What if there <del>are</del> massless quarks?  Not the up, down, bottom, top, strange, and charmed, but (for the sake of discussion) 6 "dark" quarks without mass.  It wouldn't be the first time in history new particles were "discovered".  My point is, there are nearly infinite explanations for the noncompliant actions of quantum particles.  Maybe the simulation programmers haven't gotten to that algorithm yet. :)
snippet.textOriginal: Since the 6 quark particles are derived from a model which requires them to have mass, it doesn't work to solve the strong CP problem. What if there -are- massless quarks?  Not the up, down, bottom, top, strange, and charmed, but (for the sake of discussion) 6 "dark" quarks without mass.  It wouldn't be the first time in history new particles were "discovered".  My point is, there are nearly infinite explanations for the noncompliant actions of quantum particles.  Maybe the simulation programmers haven't gotten to that algorithm yet. :)

snippet.textDisplay:
You mentioned the monkey thing because you KNEW that's not actually a settled issue, didn't you.

"Monkey" is not a scientific term, so it's not entirely sensible to hold it to standards of scientific rigor. It's similar to groups like "fish" or "lizard" - a paraphyletic taxon of species that seem intuitively similar, but which doesn't actually describe a real clade - and that's just fine for informal usage. It's also why fighting over whether a chimpanzee is a monkey or not is a fool's errand - without a rigorous definition all we can fall back on is how the word is used, and not everyone uses it the same way. You might as well argue over what temperatures correspond to "hot" and "cold".

However, some people want to get rid of terms like this, or at least change their definitions to line up with modern cladistics - for example, this guy ( https://paoloviscardi.com/2011/04/21/apes-are-monkeys-deal-with-it/ ). Why do this when Simiiformes is already a perfectly good term? Well, for one hardly anyone has heard of it, and for another pedants need to keep arguing or they'll suffocate.

No, I didn't mix them up with sharks. I mean, who ever heard of sharks arguing?

It's also why fighting over whether a chimpanzee is a monkey or not is a fool's errand - without a rigorous definition all we can fall back on is how the word is used, and not everyone uses it the same way. Why do this when Simiiformes is already a perfectly good term? Well, for one hardly anyone has heard of it, and for another pedants need to keep arguing or they'll suffocate.

snippet.textDisplay: How far away are these duplicate universes can't be answered that simply.  Yes it would be 10^10^90 times the size of the observable universe before you can expect to see duplicates.  But this is probability and there is a non-zero chance that a perfect duplicate of our observable universe is right next door.
snippet.textOriginal: How far away are these duplicate universes can't be answered that simply. snippet.textDisplay:
comment on your comments: newer versions of the theory of evolution use cladistics as a classification system, so everything still is what it once was because you never lose your cladistic classification. So... humans are great apes, humans are monkeys, humans are even reptiles and fish, humans are vertebrates, humans are eukaryotes.



Chimps are also apes, monkeys, and fish, and eukaryotes.

Aron Ra has a great series on cladistics - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AXQP_R-yiuw&list=PLXJ4dsU0oGMLnubJLPuw0dzD0AvAHAotW

snippet.textDisplay:
so when conversion of photons into axions happens, do the axions slow down a bit due to having mass, just to speed up again when converting back into photons ?
if speeding back up to c (whether instantly so or not), wouldnt some of that light oscillate a teensy wee bit in itself, since it s going faster-slower-faster-slower all the time ?
if not speeding back up, does that portion of light lose speed over time due to converting back and forth, until some condition is met ?
would those changes be measurable ? if yes, could we check some source in the universe,
like the background radiation, quasars and whatnot for those oscillating changes and of the "amount" of light that should be there against our expected/calculated values ?


just some of the questions that come to mind. Instead of trying to force their conversion, we could check for some of those values. though i dont know how realistic
these ideas are, i have like no knowledge at all compared.
